urn:contentItem:69WT-R0X1-JCMC-W086-00000-00A 4-year-old went fishing on Lake Michigan and found an 152-year-old shipwreck2023-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:18ZLexisNexisCHICAGO NEWSA 4-year-old went fishing on Lake Michigan and found an 152-year-old shipwreckClaire Thornton, USA TODAY

Henley Wollak has a lively imagination.

Every night at bedtime, the 5-year-old becomes a sea creature, tucked beneath a bedspread decorated with a massive mermaid tail, her human legs hidden under the covers.

A fairy tale came true for Henley last summer on the waters of Lake Michigan when the Peshtigo, Wisconsin, girl discovered a 150-year-old shipwreck.

Henley and her dad were boating toward her favorite island beach when they saw something under the surface that Henley thought was an octopus. Her dad, Tim Wollak, knew that hundreds of vessels had been lost to the lake over the years that were never recovered. He thought the long grey lines below the water looked like the hull of a ship. He later posted photos of their mysterious underwater discovery on Facebook.

Link to Image

“At first when we saw it in the boat, I thought it was cool to see something like that," Wollak, 36, told USA TODAY. "At that time I didn’t know the magnitude of what it was.”

This month the Wisconsin Historical Society delivered news that was beyond the father and daughter's wildest dreams: They had discovered a long-lost 150-year-old shipwreck.

Researchers said last week they believe the ship Henley and her dad spotted is the remains of the George L. Newman, a vessel built before the Civil War. Historical records show that it sank in 1871 after struggling to navigate through heavy smoke from the Peshtigo Fire, the deadliest forest fire in U.S. history.

Link to Image

Until this year, the Newman had never been spotted, researchers told Wollak. As the Wisconsin Historical Society explained in a Facebook post, the ship was abandoned, became covered with sand and was "largely forgotten – until it became exposed and was located by the Wollaks this past summer."

“I was blown away by it, especially being able to share it with Henley," Wollak said.

​Thornton, Claire​

Father-daughter outing led to discovery

On Aug. 13, Henley asked her dad if they could go swimming off the southeast shore of Lake Michigan's Green Island. She wanted to look for rocks and sea glass. Her dad wanted to go fishing, he told USA TODAY.

The two struck a compromise. Wollak agreed to take Henley to her favorite spot, driving their motorboat boat "real slow" along the route there, to look for fish.

That's when they saw what they later learned was the George L. Newman. Wollak gave his daughter full credit for placing them where they were when they made the find.

“She ultimately put us in that location because that’s where she wanted to swim," Wollak said.

Link to Image

Maritime archaeologist Tamara Thomsen told FOX 11 News in Green Bay that local researchers "didn't have anything" about a shipwreck documented in the area where the Wollaks found the George L. Newman.

"It's a pretty significant shipwreck, pretty old for Wisconsin shipwrecks," Thomsen said about the vessel. Historical records say the vessel was more than 40 yards long and 9 yards wide.

Link to Image

Wisconsin shipwreck sank in 1871

Officials from the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources later went out to Henley's spot on the lake to capture sonar scans of the wreck. Historians said the ship on the lake bottom matched the measurements and best-estimated location of the wrecked George L. Newman.

The ship was built in 1855 in Ohio, and it was a three-masted barkentine, akin to a schooner, according to the Wisconsin Historical Society. On its last voyage in October 1871, the Newman was transporting lumber from Little Suamico, Wisconsin, according to the society.

Historians said the ship was sailing blind that day through thick smoke from the Peshtigo Fire, a forest fire that surrounded Lake Michigan's Green Bay and killed more than 1,200 people, according to the National Weather Service.

"To have it tied to the Peshtigo fire makes it even more special," Thomsen, the archeologist, told FOX 11 News.

Link to Image

The smoke was so dense that the Green Island lighthouse keeper left the light on throughout the daylight hours, which is when the George L. Newman ran aground on the southeast point of Green Island, the historical society said. The lighthouse keeper rescued the crew, who stayed at the lighthouse for a week, and they salvaged what they could from the wrecked vessel.

Henley, who recently turned 5, may not completely understand the historical significance of her discovery, her father said.

“She has such a love for the outdoors, I think as she gets older the magnitude of this will sink in for her," Wollak said.

For now, Henley is most excited for next summer, when lake waters will be warm enough to go swimming again. Fishing is growing on her too.

And gazing out of her dad's boat down into the sparkling waters of Lake Michigan will always hold a special place in her heart.

urn:contentItem:6B08-13W1-DY7R-R30N-00000-00Research from Forest Research Institute Yields New Study Findings on Forestry (Rules for the construction of firebreaks along public roads in selected European countries)2023-12-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:18ZLexisNexisAGRICULTURE - FORESTRYResearch from Forest Research Institute Yields New Study Findings on Forestry (Rules for the construction of firebreaks along public roads in selected European countries)


2023 DEC 29 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Agriculture Daily -- Investigators publish new report on forestry. According to news reporting from the Forest Research Institute by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Firebreaks are one of the protective measures used to safeguard forests in case of fire."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Forest Research Institute: "Their purpose is to limit the possibility of fire spreading. This article describes how these protective measures are implemented along public roads in selected European countries. Based on the information gathered, it was found that there is a wide variety of approaches to firebreaks' construction, mostly due to different climatic and geomorphological conditions that influence the overall risk of forest fires. The forms of firebreaks used in Europe along public roads are either a mineralised belt (without vegetation) or a cleared belt of materials that are particularly susceptible to ignition and fire spread. Methods combining both are also used."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "In Poland, there is a Type A belt, that is, a 30-m-wide belt at the border of a roadway or a facility that is free of dead trees, lying branches and felled or broken trees. In the absence of pan-European rules on preventive measures to protect forests from road fires, it might be helpful to establish a set of best practices that could assist in the revision of guidelines in individual countries."
For more information on this research see: Rules for the construction of firebreaks along public roads in selected European countries. Folia Forestalia Polonica, 2023,65(4). urn:contentItem:6CDH-0BJ1-DY37-5002-00000-00ACT 10 ENDED UNION RIGHTS2024-07-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:19ZLexisNexisFRONTPg. A1ACT 10 ENDED UNION RIGHTSRULING IS LATEST WRINKLE IN SAGA THAT RESHAPED STATEPUBLIC EMPLOYEES STATE JOURNAL

A Dane County judge's ruling just ahead of the July 4 holiday that provisions of Wisconsin's 13-year-old Act 10 law are unconstitutional struck a significant blow to former Republican Gov. Scott Walker's signature legislation, which eliminated nearly all collective bargaining rights for most public employees.

While the full implications of Judge Jacob Frost's ruling remain unclear, here's what to know about the law and where it stands now.

What is Act 10?

Signed by Walker in 2011, Act 10 undid collective bargaining for most public employees, while providing exemptions for public safety employees like police officers and firefighters.

The law effectively ended collective bargaining for most public-sector unions by allowing them to bargain solely over base wage increases no greater than inflation. It also ended the automatic withdrawal of union dues, required annual recertification votes for unions, and forced public workers to pay more for health insurance and retirement benefits.

It was passed when Republicans held a trifecta in state government as a way to address a projected $3.6 billion budget deficit and delivered a windfall to taxpayers while also altering the relationship between government workers and their employers. The proposal sparked immense pushback, with as many as 100,000 people massing at the Capitol for a nearly monthlong protest and occupation leading up to the measure's passage.

At one point, 14 Senate Democrats even fled the state in an attempt to deny Republicans a quorum and block a vote on the legislation, prompting then-Senate Majority Leader Scott Fitzgerald to sign warrants ordering their detention and forcible return to Madison. The lawmakers returned of their own accord after Republicans found a procedural workaround and passed the legislation without them.

While "general" public employees such as teachers, administrative staff and sanitation workers saw their collective bargaining rights stripped away, employees classified as "public safety" workers like local police officers, state troopers and firefighters were permitted to continue collective bargaining.

Critics say the the law's definition of public safety workers is arbitrary, including some workers like motor vehicle inspectors in the safety realm, but not others, like conservation wardens, Capitol police and members of the UW-Madison Police Department.

A Wisconsin State Journal review of Act 10's impact found the law offered Wisconsinites cheaper government, lower taxes and a way out of the immediate budget crisis. The cost of those benefits was borne by public employees, and Act 10 exacerbated inequality among certain sectors of public workers.

So how did we get here?

Frost's ruling came in response to a lawsuit was filed late last year by the Abbotsford Education Association, Beaver Dam Education Association, SEIUWisconsin, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees Locals 47 and 1215, Teaching Assistants' Association Local 3220 and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 695, as well AFSCME Local 1215 president Ben Gruber, Beaver Dam teacher Matthew Ziebarth and Racine Unified School District employee Wayne Rasmussen.

The plaintiffs argued that Act 10's exemption of some public safety workers from the bargaining restrictions violates the Wisconsin Constitution's equal protection clause by treating public workers with similar work duties differently.

Frost sided with the plaintiffs in his assessment, noting that just seven of the 22 "protective occupations" outlined in state statute that form the basis of what constitutes a "public safety" employee are exempted from the restrictions of Act 10.

Specifically, the law exempts the following public safety professions: members of the state patrol, state motor vehicle inspectors, police officers, firefighters, deputy sheriffs, county traffic police officers and combined village protective services officers.

Other protective service professions, however, are subject to the restrictions imposed by Act 10: conservation wardens, conservation patrol boat captains, conservation patrol boat engineers, conservation pilots, conservation patrol officers, forest fire control assistants, sheriffs, undersheriffs, state probation and parole officers, state forest rangers, fire watchers at Wisconsin veterans facilities, state correctional-psychiatric officers, excise tax investigators, special criminal investigation agents and assistant or deputy fire marshals.

The law's differential treatment between "general" and "public safety" employees and also within the public safety group violates the state constitution's guarantee of equal protection for all, Frost said.

Plaintiffs also noted in court filings that those exempted from collective bargaining restrictions endorsed Walker in the 2010 gubernatorial election, while those subject to the restrictions did not.

Hasn't the law been challenged before?

Yes. Attorneys for the Legislature and state Department of Justice argued for the case to be dismissed because previous legal challenges against Act 10 have failed. They've also said union officials waited too long to bring the latest legal challenge.

Assistant Attorney General Steven Kilpatrick, who is representing state agencies in the case, said in May the Legislature, when crafting Act 10, chose to exempt specific public safety employees because of the irreparable harm that would be caused if those employees chose to illegally strike.

Shortly after the law was passed, a Dane County judge barred its enforcement because of an alleged open meetings violation by a legislative committee, but the state Supreme Court overturned that action in June 2011.

In March 2012, a federal court struck down some parts of the law in a challenge by the Wisconsin Education Association Council, but it was later upheld in its entirety by a federal appeals court.

That same year, a Dane County judge struck down key parts of the law as it applied to school and municipal workers. The ruling was appealed, and in 2014 the then-conservative-leaning state Supreme Court upheld the law, ruling that public workers in Wisconsin do not have a constitutional right to bargain collectively.

In 2013, a Dane County judge dismissed a law enforcement union lawsuit that argued the law violated union members' rights to free speech and association.

What does the Walker recall have to do with this?

The passage of Act 10 created a political earthquake in Wisconsin. After the law was signed, opponents launched an ultimately unsuccessful recall election against Walker and Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch in 2012. Recall elections were also instituted against 13 Republican senators, three of which succeeded.

The former Government Accountability Board's posting of electronic versions of the Walker recall petitions spawned a cottage industry of online sleuths hunting for people in public office and the media who signed the petitions and thus might have a conflict of interest.

Frost, who Democratic Gov. Tony Evers appointed as a Dane County Circuit Court judge in 2020, appears to have signed the petition while he was a private practice attorney specializing in civil litigation and family law. Frost previously served as board president of Access to Independence, which provides services and advocacy to people with disabilities.

The Wisconsin Code of Judicial Conduct is silent on recall petitions, but state judges cannot take part in political party or candidate activities and should avoid "the appearance of impropriety."

No parties in the case have filed a formal request seeking Frost's recusal.

But Republicans were quick to condemn the judge. Senate Majority Leader Devin LeMahieu, R-Oostburg, called the ruling "yet another example of courts legislating from the bench."

On the social media site X, Walker asked, "Why elect a Governor and lawmakers if activist judges can impose their own will?!?"

What happens next?

The immediate implications of Frost's ruling remain unclear, though it is almost certain to be appealed.

That means the Wisconsin Supreme Court, which last year shifted to a liberal majority for the first time in more than a decade, is likely to have the final say on the matter.

Justice Janet Protasiewicz, who joined the court in August, also signed the Walker recall petition and said while campaigning she believes Act 10 is unconstitutional. She also said she would consider recusing herself from any legal challenges against the law.

Frost has given the plaintiffs 14 days to file a letter with the court indicating what sections of Act 10 should be severed and struck under his ruling, or file to take some other action. Defendants in the case have 14 days after that to respond.

urn:contentItem:6636-RHX1-JC5B-G269-00000-00Berlin forest fire contained but ammo depot still a problem2022-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:18ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSBerlin forest fire contained but ammo depot still a problemBERLIN

BERLIN (AP) — A fire accompanied by explosions at a police ammunition depot in a Berlin forest was contained and large parts of it were extinguished Friday, but officials said they were determining whether the ammunition stored at the facility needed to be stabilized and cooled down.

The fire broke out early Thursday in the Grunewald forest, located on the western edge of the German capital. The area burning is far from the nearest homes, and no one had to be evacuated, although a nearby highway and railway line remained closed.

Authorities declared a 1,000-meter (more than half-mile) exclusion zone around the depot. Berlin's fire service said wildfires on the ground in the area around the storage site were largely extinguished by Friday morning. Cooler weather with at least a little rain brightened the outlook.

The ammunition dump itself, though, remained a problem. Experts approached it in armored vehicles to locate ammunition that might still pose a risk, fire service chief Karsten Homrighausen said.

They were evaluating whether crews need to cool down the stored supplies to prevent more detonations and if officials can scale back the exclusion zone. The German military said trying to drop water on the site from the air wasn't an option.

It remains unclear what triggered the first explosions at the ammunition dump. The site was created in Cold War-era West Berlin in 1950, and 25 metric tons or more of fireworks, World War II ammunition and other explosive ordnance was stored there before the fire started. Controlled blasts are carried out at the site twice a year.

urn:contentItem:6B07-DRN1-F11P-X44Y-00000-00Renewable Energy Tech to Watch in 20242023-12-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:19ZLexisNexisRenewable Energy Tech to Watch in 2024

As we surge into 2024, the renewable energy sector is buzzing with innovations that promise a greener, more sustainable future. Let's dive into the technologies that are shaping the renewable landscape and could revolutionize how we generate and consume energy.

1. Wave Energy Converters: The Waveline Magnet

Source: Sea Wave Energy Ltd – SWEL/YouTube

The Waveline Magnet, a vibrant yellow raft-like structure, has been making waves in the renewable sector. Over a decade of development has culminated in this device that not only promises efficient wave energy harnessing but also lends itself to applications like desalination and hydrogen fuel production. Its adaptable size makes it a versatile solution for various maritime conditions. As companies gear up for commercial production, focusing initially on desalination, the Waveline Magnet represents a major stride in tapping into the ocean's boundless energy.

2. Fusion Power: The Sun's Energy on Earth

Fusion power, the process that powers the sun, has long been an elusive goal for scientists. However, recent breakthroughs at facilities like the National Ignition Facility have sparked new hope. Achieving net energy gain from fusion reactions opens up a realm of possibilities for a clean, almost limitless energy source. As global efforts like ITER and JET progress, the dream of a fusion-powered future inches closer to reality.

3. Solar Innovations: Beyond Rooftop Panels

Solar energy continues to be a frontrunner in the renewable market, but it's the novel applications that are catching eyes in 2024. Vehicles like the Aptera have been designed from the ground up to maximize solar energy efficiency, integrating solar panels into their very structure. Meanwhile, the concept of transparent solar panels is transforming windows into power generators, with companies like Solar Window leading the charge. Even forest fire detection is getting a solar boost, with technologies like Dryad Networks‘ ‘electric noses' providing early alerts by detecting burning materials.

As we look forward to a year filled with promising advancements, these renewable energy technologies stand out not just for their innovation but for their potential to significantly impact our approach to sustainable living. Keep an eye on these developments as they move from prototypes to part of our everyday lives, steering us toward a cleaner, greener future.

BERLIN — A fire accompanied by explosions at a police ammunition depot in a Berlin forest was contained and large parts of it were extinguished Friday, but officials said they were determining whether the ammunition stored at the facility needed to be stabilized and cooled down.

The fire broke out early Thursday in the Grunewald forest, located on the western edge of the German capital. The area burning is far from the nearest homes, and no one had to be evacuated, although a nearby highway and railway line remained closed.

Authorities declared a 1,000-meter (more than half-mile) exclusion zone around the depot. Berlin's fire service said wildfires on the ground in the area around the storage site were largely extinguished by Friday morning. Cooler weather with at least a little rain brightened the outlook.

The ammunition dump itself, though, remained a problem. Experts approached it in armored vehicles to locate ammunition that might still pose a risk, fire service chief Karsten Homrighausen said.

They were evaluating whether crews need to cool down the stored supplies to prevent more detonations and if officials can scale back the exclusion zone. The German military said trying to drop water on the site from the air wasn't an option.

It remains unclear what triggered the first explosions at the ammunition dump. The site was created in Cold War-era West Berlin in 1950, and 25 metric tons or more of fireworks, World War II ammunition and other explosive ordnance was stored there before the fire started. Controlled blasts are carried out at the site twice a year.

urn:contentItem:67R1-JSF1-JC5B-G3KF-00000-00New Jersey Pinelands fire that threatened homes is contained2023-03-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:37:18ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONALNew Jersey Pinelands fire that threatened homes is containedWAYNE PARRYAssociated PressLITTLE EGG HARBOR, N.J.

LITTLE EGG HARBOR, N.J. (AP) — A wind-whipped forest fire in the southern New Jersey Pinelands that threatened 16 homes Tuesday was fully contained by nightfall, and firefighters said they believed the homes were no longer in jeopardy.

No injuries or damage to property occurred from the fire, which burned 418 acres before being declared 100% contained about eight hours after it started.

Winds gusting between 30 and 40 mph fanned the flames. But the fire was burning in a remote, uninhabited section of the Stafford Forge Wildlife Management Area in Little Egg Harbor Township, just west of Exit 58 of the Garden State Parkway in southern Ocean County.

No one had to be evacuated, even as fire trucks and water tankers were positioned near the homes that firefighters considered potentially vulnerable to the blaze, said Greg McLaughlin, administrator of the New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

“The wind has been ripping all day. But it's been consistently in one direction, which helps,” he said.

Also hampering the fire's spread were numerous marshy bogs within the wildlife area that are wet from spring rains, McLaughlin said.

The fire was spotted from an aerial observation tower in the Pinelands at 11:44 a.m.

State, county and local investigators were looking into how it might have started, but no cause was immediately apparent, McLaughlin said.

The fire service has been doing controlled burns in the Pinelands in recent weeks to consume dead leaves, twigs and other forest floor fuel that could accelerate a wildfire. There were no burns being done anywhere else in the state on Tuesday because of the high winds, officials said.

About 45 firefighters used 11 trucks, numerous water tankers, a bulldozer and a helicopter to fight the fire.

The fire was burning not far from the Air National Guard's Warren Grove target range, where a 2007 forest fire burned 17,000 acres.
